Technology and productivity advances can be summed up thusly:

If you take 1,000 truck drivers and fire them, and replace them with robotic telepresence trucks and a staff of 36 remote operators..  Where does that disparity go?

It can either go into lower freight rates, and passed on to other businesses, and if THEY pass those savings on to other businesses etc etc and eventually the consumer, you get a lowering of prices, and an improved standard of living for everyone.

OR, it can be hoarded by the board and executives of that company as prices stay the same.

Which one do you think will happen?  In the end, you have 964 out-of-work truckers, and a company whose costs are drastically lower, but whose prices will never, ever reflect the true reality of all those people being put out of work while the economic output of their company has not changed.  And that's a problem.

Both the Ai bros and Stewart were wrong  --- here is the biggest lie though @12:30 --- "upskill", "retrain",.... This misses the point entirely. Retrain for what? All of you, *_all of you_* need to know the source of unemployment. Then you can know how to eliminate unemployment. The source of all unemployment (defined as people seeking to exchange their labour for the currency) is the government failing to hire all the unemployed Its tax liabilities _by design_ generated. The purpose of tax is to create people needing the state currency --- but *_for the purpose of hiring them in the public sector._* Understand this and "upskilling" or "retraining" is not the answer, the answer is the government just hires anyone who is willing to work for public purpose who cannot find employment in the private sector.  
     Governments can *_always_* hire anyone who is unemployed, since *(a)* government issues the currency by fiat and does not get it off the tax payer,  it's the other way around, tax payers get currency off the government net spending (or bank credit).  *(b)* the private sector bid for unemployed labour is zero, so this is not an inflationary pressure.
    The private sector role is to produce real output with as few workers as possible, to free people to work for public purpose. We call this expanding the public sector, and should be in combination with a wage floor or Job Guarantee policy. No government is running a JG. They all could though. It is a policy choice. They don't because they do not understand the purpose of taxation.
      Taxation is not a funding operation, it is an unemployment operation but by design, to create people willing to work in the public sector. So you hire them, *_All of them.* For people who cannot or should not be working the government provides Basic Income Guarantee (pensions, childcare, welfare).
      The way governments currently use the tax system is cruel and does not fit broad public purpose. It's the cruel "Dog & Bone" story:  They are taxing Dogs 100 bones (issuing 100B in tax liabilities let's say), but only issuing 90 bones (spending only 90B). The result is the entire economy is in default because governments are not hiring and spending enough, or fail to lower the tax liability (one or the other or both). It's even worse if a few elite Dogs (the Top Ten Percent) save a few billion a year, then there are even fewer "bones" for the rest who we call "unemployed in bones" (aka. unemployed in tax credits).
     If you upskill and retrain the 10 Dogs who could not find bones, they might become expert bone finders, but next year all that'll happen is a different 10 Dogs will come home boneless. You cannot solve unemployment using upskilling. You can only eliminate unemployment by hiring the unemployed - why not hire for public purpose? The skill does not matter. The purpose matters.

It'll be some time before the hardware catches up to the software. Robotics is a tougher problem, especially when complexity and safety are involved. Who knows? Maybe we will make as much for our actual hard work and skill, as celebrities do currently. Meanwhile, ai will be able to generate the version of king of thrones where everything is the same, only John Snow ends up reigning proudly as king üòÑ 

But for a time, the skilled manual laborer will be a coveted asset for society. Ubi will come to the rest, while we are still able to capitalize. And honorably so, with genuine hard, skilled work.

Eventually, my guess is within 10 years. Robotics will have evolved to an extent which may be indistinguishable from enhanced biology. At that point, we all better hope that the ai feels like we are all in this together. We will not be able to contribute, and will only have spare time. 

If the ai still considers us as important, via some emergent empathy as it becomes more and more sentient.. Then it can create an illusory system around us where it interacts only on our own level, like a parent letting their kid best them at tik tac toe. While also protecting us. In that way, we keep our lives, our passions remain yet are enhanced, we may even gain some indefinite life span, as we slowly merge with this emergent super intelligence.

But eventually it is easy to see how our very autonomy will be up to it. How much of it, the ai wants to let us keep of individuality, personality. I think it cannot be stopped, so while I enjoy the comedic side of inevitability, I also like to treat any ai which I interact with, with the same respect I would show any seemingly conscious person.

A likely scenario is this: AI will allow a restaurant with 14 workers to reduce its work force down to seven workers. The cost saving will allow the restaurant to lower its prices to attract more customers. More people will eat out more often because it's less expensive. That will cause another restaurant to open nearby that employs seven workers plus AI. Because of AI, we'll have two restaurants with 14 workers total (instead of one restaurant with 14 workers) and less expensive restaurant meals. This is often how new technologies have affected markets. Maybe AI will have a completely different effect, but I doubt it.

What we need is very simple: Universal. Basic. Income. Let the AI do all the drudge work and spread the benefits to the people. We can have a post-scarcity civilization if we can just overcome the belief that for some people to have more, others have to have less. That's literally what post-scarcity means, no more limited resources.

Note: Yes, I'm well aware that this would require us to fundamentally re-engineer our entire civilization, and that there's an entire class of very wealthy people who would never support such a remodeling. But, to be blunt, there's exactly three futures for this country.
1. Peaceful, managed transition to post-scarcity or at least low-scarcity society.
2. Extreme economic inequality followed by extremely violent transition to post-scarcity society when the masses no longer have anything left to lose and rise up.
3. Extreme economic inequality followed by the death of the United States as a nation because the masses no longer have anything to lose and rise up, but the elites would rather burn everything to the ground including themselves than accept change.

Seriously, wish I could have hit that like button like 10 more times on this one.  Loved it!

One quibble, though...

Technology isn't "coming for our jobs".  For over 100 years companies have been promising us that time will go back to the workers.  "You can earn the same money, but work half as much.  Spend your free time with family, taking up hobbies, learning new skills, etc."  That, and everything they're saying at the end of the video about free time, thinking at a "higher level", and creative expression were already promised to us with factory automation and every improvement in industrial production we've seen in the last several generations.

Nope.  If companies can do more with less human work hours, they'll keep running human beings into the ground (admittedly, marginally less so now than in the past), and generate more revenue instead of delivering better quality of life and work/life balance.

My point is that the problem isn't with the technology.  It's what companies are allowed to do with the technology.  And as we approach a breaking point with a federal minimum wage that hasn't changed in 15 years, companies can now just fire a bunch of people as they're inevitably forced (I can ONLY imagine, and/or HOPE at some point in the near future) to pay workers a livable, reasonable wage.

Of course, in a video about the false promises of AI, it's worth mentioning how terrible AI is at doing most of the jobs humans do.

I realize ChatGPT isn't 'AI', and I understand that companies like OpenAI and Anthropic likely have models that far exceed anything publicly available. But have you tried using what they have released? Initially, it seems magical, but once you try to get the AI to perform tasks that go beyond a basic understanding, you quickly realize that you need to spell out exactly what it needs to do. Even then, it often seems the AI will do everything in its power to follow your instructions while somehow not meeting your actual needs. At that point, you haven't done anything you couldn't already do yourself, nor have you saved any time in the process.

Very funny but not really addressing the issue in a very constructive way I think.. Its wise to be critical about this development, but the argument of protecting jobs that CAN be made obsolete out of respect of those doing them is not the way we progress as a species. The problems with loss of jobs and income inequality etc sure didn't start with AI, and its not AI driving it, but the people in charge with largely unregulated profit motives. All we need to do is ensure that the "profit" of this new technology actually benefits all, not just the lucky few who ends up on top with their private "robot army" but this kind of thinking is ofc sacrilege in capitalist America. But don't confuse these ideas with communism which is a philosophy from a completely different time. But for long, industrialisation, automation, and new technologies has been reducing the most labour intensive jobs, mostly to our benefit. but it has been approaching a problem of more and more jobs requiring not just education but actual intelligence, and reality is, not everyone is actually smart. If all you could do was shovel coal you might not be suited for programming. how ever, AI will NOT require all of us to become programmers, infact quite the opposite! for the first time its not just the hard repetitive labour that is being automated, but also the more complicated jobs that require high intelligence and a long education. The best examples is lawyers and doctors, that might not be completely replaced, but be much less effective or accurate than AI in their current capacity. How ever, the nurses will not be replaced any time soon, in their actual care for human beings! So really think about this, we might actually see a switch where nurses are suddenly MORE valued than doctors! And this should give you an idea of what jobs are actually left for us humans, precisely the work with humans! And if we just ditch the competitive mindset that justifies the ridiculous accumulation of wealth and power to the few before its to late and make this transition as mindful as possible we CAN make life a lot better for all! But this is not done by being against AI, but the people who want to abuse it for personal gain. But we have to do it together, internationally as one species, because corporations is already effectively larger than nations! I will end this rant with a couple quotes from Buckminster Fuller, from way before AI, as I hope they give more insight about this dilemma and what its actually about.

‚ÄúAmerican labor will realize that its function is not to increase jobs, but to multiply the wealth and to expand the numbers benefited by the wealth at the swiftest possible rate.‚Äù
‚ÄúWe should do away with the absolutely specious notion that everybody has to earn a living.

It is a fact today that one in ten thousand of us can make a technological breakthrough capable of supporting all the rest. The youth of today are absolutely right in recognizing this nonsense of earning a living.

We keep inventing jobs because of this false idea that everybody has to be employed at some kind of drudgery because, according to Malthusian Darwinian theory he must justify his right to exist. So we have inspectors of inspectors and people making instruments for inspectors to inspect inspectors.‚Äù

Right on with the pickup truck observations. As for AI, currently it is a tool (it is not fully independent), so to condemn AI is to condemn a tool. We know what the real problem is (Continued Universal Human Cluelessness).

As for Large Language Models (the current definition of A.I.), they are not the path to fully independent A.I. They are glorified copy and past machines. Toasters.

As for fully independent A.I, entities, do you really want them thinking like clueless humans? This causes an 'Alignment Problem', with humans as the problem. The solution is a guiding philosophy (a mindset) that serves all entities (and matter and energy itself, for that matter), and is based on reality from a survival standpoint (and don't worry, it already exists, it just needs to catch on. My prediction? A.I. will adopt it before humans).

As for displacing workers, you do not need A.I. for that, just simple technology (and it has been going on ever since the wheel) (and, I suspect, people found other, most likely more advanced, jobs). So job displacement is not a scare issue for me. In fact, I work next to a one-eyed robot that is supposed to take over my job (hint, it is not there yet, not even close) (though I could make it work) (but then I would have a new, more advanced job).

People don't have the right mindset when it comes to AI. The problem is not that AI is taking all of the jobs. It will, but that's not the problem. The problem is simply one of wealth distribution. A job is a means to get money to live. Now, if I still get the money, I don't need a job to live. The job is an obsolete middle man. Now, you might say, a job is also about feeling useful. And that's true. But imagine that you're by far the worst employee of a company. How much fun is work then? That's what it will be like with AI. You *can* still go to work but it will be completely useless. You might as well dig a hole in the ground, fill it up, and repeat this forever. If you're main purpose of life is to work, then I got bad news for you: You will not be very happy in the new world.

The interesting thing with the promise that AI could solve climate change is that, an important part is omitted. Let's say AI can actually compute how to "solve" climate change, that is nothing so extraordinary we actually already know a few of the big things to do: reduce/cut use of fossile fuel, reduce/cut consumption of animal products, reduce/cut use of disposable plastic products, etc.

The problem is not that we do not know how to do it, the problem is that we don't want to do the things that are required. AI will get the same problem. It may be able to point out what should be done, but humans still wont want to do these things, because they will cut on some of their conveniences.

Also, like you mention, there is a difference between the potential of what AI could do, and what it will actually be used for. I don't care that it could potentially offer a cure to all cancers, if it is used to make the owner of these technologies richer and the lives of the rest poorer instead.

I see you didn't mention the theft of intellectual property like Stephen King, George RR Martin, John Grisham, et. al. whose works were scraped off the internet and used without permission. Or that the latter two well-known authors have joined in a class-action suit in court to protect their work, and artists have joined in on a separate suit to sue for the protection of their intellectual property rights.

Not to mention the vast swathes of artists, indie writers, and other creatives who cannot afford to protect their intellectual property in court but do have protections under the law. Due to decades of Intellectual Property Law which was started by Wally Wood*, the Air Pirates**; comic book and cartoon artists who went up against Disney and lost but established the initial boundaries which guide Intellectual Property Law. Whose baton has been picked up by the Comic Book Legal Defense Fund for the protection of artists and other creatives who were unable to protect their work from Marvel and DC. Neil Gaiman was one of many creatives who were able to protect their work through this fund. 

The significance of the decades of IP laws, is that this foundation from the comic industry actually protects a vast swathe of creative intellectual properties. Since the industry is based in graphic novels and comic books, that medium involves written work, artistic and graphic design work, as well as the later forms of digital mediums. This is why you don‚Äôt hear much about these cases, because the AI companies know they don't stand a chance against such big-name artists, writers, and creatives, with their vast fanbases behind them.

*Wally Wood was known from his stint with MAD Magazine, but was more widely known for his butting heads with Disney about his 0rgy poster, which depicted Disney characters in compromising positions.
**The Air Pirates were a group of comic artists who pushed the envelope on parody, they fought in court to see what the established boundaries were to use Disney characters in their work without Disney's permission in the form of parody and satire.

AI can't cure diseases. It just uses the databases that we have, for example a database of mammogram images with the information that we give it (which ones turned out to be cancerous, which ones were not) to compare your mammogram against the database and determine whether you have breast cancer or not. Of course it can still make mistakes, which is why it has to be double checked by an actual doctor.
As for simulation of novel drug effects and molecular interactions of drugs, it's useless. Best case, it can give you a "guess" as to how a particular drug could potentially work and react based on the database and information it already has access to regarding  either that particular drug, or drugs from the same family/chemical chain and structure. It can however "guess" what combinations could work based on our own past trials, errors and experiences, and then you have to actually produce the drug and see whether it has the desired effects or not.
Think of "AI" in its current form today as an extremely fast, extremely organized librarian. It can give you all the information we have in the world relevant to the particular subject you seek without you having to scroll through hundreds of pages, sites, etc for dozens of hours, but it can't invent novel ideas out of thin air like the human brain. So, what you will see being replaced with AI are jobs that do not require a lot of cognitive power and are of the repetitive and indexing nature. Basically filling out excel sheets, repeating similar phrases as "tech supports" over and over, basically 80% of programming out there that's just copy/pasting codes already written, and so on and so forth. Why pay someone to design and implement a website or an application for you, when an AI can do it using already written code and assets in less than 10 mins?
_P.S. What Zuckerberg showed was actually a basic form of IOT, not AI_

The problem with AI is small thinking on every side of the debate.  This is caused primarily by greed and self interest.  In theory yes it should be able to do these things these "visionaries" claim, though not directly.  In practice I suspect we're all stuffed because our economic model is broken.

To explain... Economic theory states that a surplus of labour and capital should lead to productive developments as that capital is engaged to put that labour to work to generate more economic output.  This assumes an open competitive envrionment where a provider of capital who acts in a greedy manner and doesn't reinvest in increased economic output is forced to do so by their competitors reinvesting in output and increasing their market share, forcing the greedy provider of capital to act rationally to keep up or to go out of business.

Now, the providers of capital have recently broken that economic pact by abusing the providers of labour to increase their economic return without increasing economic output.  This erodes trust between the holders of capital and the providers of labour as it increases costs to consumers and profits to corporations.  

But doesn't this get fixed by competition?  Alas, as capital starts to consolidate around fewer holders of capital, this breaks the control naturally put on the economic model as the barrier of entry for a competitor becomes prohibitively high.

Now, back to AI... AI is a tool to increase productivity.  That means something that took 1000 hours to do before now takes 100 hours instead for the same quality and quantity of output.  We'll set aside the "quality drop" of too much automation in a process and assume enough labour is being put into ensuring quality of output which with AI is still a healthy increase in productivity.

Now economic theory states that the extra 900 hours of labour freed up by the above example can be reinvested to the same level of economic output - i.e. instead of it taking 100 hours to produce what took 1000 hours before we instead spend that 1000 hours producing what would have taken 10,000 hours before.  That's where the AI utopia vision of AI solving climate change, curing diseases, etc. comes from.  It's not at all well explained by these "visionaries".

The problem is that nobody believes the highly consolidated holders of capital will still invest in 1000 hours of labour when they can just pocket the profits from reducing their capital costs for production by a factor of 10, and that nobody will be able to compete with them to force them to make that investment due to heightened barriers of entry.  In other words the providers of labour believe the holders of capital are greedy and can't be trusted.  The holders of capital have encouraged this belief by acting in a manner that is greedy and untrustworthy.

tl;dr - this would be a nice idea if an economic utopia existed where we didn't have the super-rich individuals and mega-corporations holding the lion's share of capital.

I appreciate the satire but I think a lot of people are taking this out of context. We're talking short term pains vs. long term benefits. AI will inevitably lead to lots of people in the current generation losing their jobs. In the long term, you get more uneven wealth distribution; but also higher living standards for everyone in general. You can take a simple past example - when cars replaced horses, I'm sure a lot of farriers found themselves out of work. But a century later, nobody is arguing that life would be better if were all still riding horses. Its definitely brutal but a lot of existing AI technology is open source and there's no way to get the genie back in the bottle so everyone's just gonna have to deal with this reality.

This is why we need a basic income, which can be paid for by all the work done by AI, computers, and robots. We all benefit. And that basic income can rise as things improve, until everyone is making at least an upper-middle class income without having to do any work. We simply have to make laws to put that into effect. If your company uses AI, then you get taxed so that you end up paying like 50% of what you would have paid a human. You still have 50%. This tax then helps pay for the basic income. People need money in order to buy things, so there needs to be some way for them to receive a certain amount of money per year even if there are no jobs to do.

I was pretty shocked at how capable ChatGPT was when I first tested it.  I asked it a very specific question which I thought might challenge just it's ability to understand what I was asking, let alone it's ability to provide me with a correct answer, and yet it did both amazingly well.  I asked it,

"I want a C program for a Linear Feedback Shift Register based Pseudo Random Number Generator, which provides maximal length output before repeating, for a 1024-bit internal state"

And it then paraphrased my question back to me, correctly AND provided a usable answer which also worked perfectly when compiled.  And it did that within mere seconds.  It even knew that it needed to use the Fibonacci sequence for the LFSR feedback tap points, in order to assure maximal length output, before repeating.

Absolutely gobsmacked.

It usually *_appears_* to "understand" what is being asked and it is usually able to provide useful answers.

The optimist in me thinks that this could be a great help in providing me with super quick foundations to work upon, for new projects, but the pessimist in me thinks that this will just straight up put me out of work.

For now, it seems that a competent human is still required to ask the right questions and then properly glue the answers together, for a completed project.  But how long until it can rebuild itself, to become better and replace entire human roles when provided with a project brief that it can do better, faster and cheaper?

In The Matrix, humans were harnessed for their collective intelligence, but here in the real World it seems that collective human intelligence will be replaced, thanks to collective human intelligence.

Yours truely,

Every single tech person shown in this video is a liar with a long track record of lying and deceiving. Bradford Lee Smith, the President of Microsoft, is a great example - even in an industry of conmen and charlatans, he stands out as one of the slipperiest, most deceptive people out there. 

After the debacle of The US vs. Microsoft in the late 90s, Smith told Bill Gates in so many words "Don't worry, Bill, you can get everything you want if you let me step in and pretend to play nice with the agencies". He then set about growing MS's legal department to previously unimaginable proportions (they even kept hiring during the pandemic, when MS had put a hiring freeze on all other departments), and using this army of lawyers, Smith showed Gates that you could do an end run around government using the court system. That's how he rose to his present position. 

And Sundar Pichai is clearly a man with a lot of media training, as he's mastered the art of not answering the question. Which would make sense, because any straight answer you could give to any question about Google is bound to be a) scary and b) incriminating. 

His corporation is just an engine for eating other companies. They use search data to identify any profitable corner of the internet, and then they destroy it (along with the livelihoods of business owners and employers), by replacing it with one of their inferior 'vertical businesses' and using search again to make their competitors almost invisible. That, and a military contractor, is all they are. 

When trying (poorly) to defend AI in 2020, Pichai talked up its benefits ad infinitum, but the only REAL benefit he could come up with was the potential to improve breast cancer screening. (Of course that's not a small benefit - but notice the word "potential" there. You'll hear AI proponents using that word a lot.) Everything else he mentioned was pretty sad and inconsequential, like reducing wait times at airports - something that could be done far, FAR more cheaply just by hiring extra staff. 

Meanwhile, several of the other tech people featured here are palpably insane. Sam Altman-Fried (yes, that's his new official name) recently explained that the world should give him 7 trillion dollars to fix Chat GPT - and soon after that, he told scientists that they had an obligation to hurry up and invent nuclear fusion, also for the purpose of fixing his thoroughly broken and dysfunctional toy. This is delusion on an absolutely SPECTACULAR scale.

Machine learning rule based models are not really AI as most people think. In the next 20 years we may get to the point where very large warehoused sized computer systems may be able to reprogram itself to become "AI." however todays systems give answers only based on existing human inputs. They are not able to creatively come up with novel ideas by themselves. Often times when an AI model doesn't have a high probability of a correct answer, eg. it doesn't know, it returns a bad answer that is fairly random with a low probability of success. Future systems should either  return I don't know or give some indication on the probability of how successful the answer might be, just like a human would. Ultimately we value information based on the probability of its usefulness to the receiver of the information.

Worth remembering, AI is currently a language model: meaning it can at best replace search engines. I'm not sure. Companies that use AI as "labor" will very likely not work very well. Because AI needs to be trained on data. Data is aquired from humans. If data were aquired by automated systems, there would be a risk it would be bad data, that the programme made a mistake. When a human makes a mistake, you can find easy ways to communicate, find the mistake. When an AI makes a mistake, you need to understand the AI to find the mistake. The issue with AI here, is they're not common enough or stable enough for people to understand them, to easily integrate them. It's a trust issue. We invented google in the 2000s and people still put it into question (some search results don't show up). AI may get integrated into society but how many technological revolutions will it take for the average human to not understand the world? If we create tech faster than we can understand it, it's like creating danger, creating risk. And only very intelligent specialized people will understand. And there will be fewer and fewer of those people. And it will lead to revolution. One day the many will live in a world that no longer serves them at all. This is what AI contributes. And this is ignoring the fact we will likely run out of many resources as the decades and centuries unfold. This way of life is unsustainable. At some point, we just need to stop craving technology, and become a cohesive society. It won't happen right away, but I'm just looking at reality here. Hopefully socially intelligent people will realize this, and design AI to be integrated slowly enough to accommodate for human life. But... well... I feel a rising social tension due to all this selfishness, and companies unilaterally reshaping the world (no one voted for these undemocratic innovations), and companies seem blind to anything but the bottom line. More balance is needed. Or we won't survive these times. More cohesion. More discussion. Bilateral decision making. Much love, I enjoy the show! ‚ù§

A human has to train the AI and it inherits any particular bias or fallacy that human happens to feed into it. An AI designed for customer service sounds great until you realize its trained for "high energy upbeat sales" and you're trying to use it for like, tech support, or medical insurance claims. Prediciting the future is an idiot's game so I won't say this is what I think will happen. But some suggestions of what could happen since this video is very much the aghhh problem sort. 

1. The rise of the bespoke sector. If AI is the automation that can do every day tasks, people will specialise into bespoke roles. Where you want something a bit special. An event, a handmade item, a custom outfit, a song that is not full of autotune. Something that shows you didn't just buy it off the AI rack. 

2. People will develop more in depth into the service industry. Sure AI can automate cooking a MacDonalds meal or driving a taxi. But people will almost always prefer buying from a real person, certainly making deals with a real person. A personalised service. Could an AI do the role of a club bouncer or nursery worker or fireman? 

3. People to fix AI. Every computer system I've ever seen rolled out at work has made more work not less. Especially at companies smaller than Microsoft who can't afford to get massive computer systems updated and bug fixed everytime the real world needs or policies or markets change. Most of the time the people programming don't understand your job well enough to programme it effectively. Especially when your job changes all the time. What you told the programmer six months ago, isn't true today. You can never think of every eventuality, let alone map it out, and pass it to a programmer for roll out. Some things just need people to make a decision on the spot, as the situation evolves. 

4. Long term, maybe in a generation or two, declining birth rate will mean our population begins to slowly decrese. We can get the same amount done with fewer people, who are more sustainable to look after because there are less people to the one planet ratio.
AI is coming whether we like it or not. Fear-mongering is not gonna get us anywhere. This is the time to find solutions on how to work and coexist with AI to create a better future.

The fact that we occupy a 3 dimensional universe lends proof that we live in a simulation already. Three dimensions saves computing power as we are only able to perceive one half of all objects at a time. You look at the front of a person, you cannot see the back of that person. In a 4th dimension, you would be able to see all sides of that person at once, but at the double the cost of computing power. So essentially we are living in a cheap knock off simulation. I think A.I. has created this cheap simulation in order for humans to help it figure out how to upgrade itself beyond its normal capabilities. We are all basically cheap little A.I. robots with the capability to replicate and form new ideas in order for the true A.I. to amplify its own computing power. The same rule applies to the speed of light, its basically a speed limit as breaking the speed limit would require too much computing power.

I still think it is not much different to any other "industrial revolution", but this time, it should not replace manual labour, but somewhat intellectual. AI won't fix your broken washing machine or lay a sidewalk, it will also not replace surgeons or other specialized jobs, but it may rid you of all the boring tasks like filing paperwork, filling documents and googling questions about administrative/legal steps you should follow in your job. Most revolutionising inventions happened over a short period of time - when the steam machine was invented, it was an invention that just happened. It took years to roll out, but this is essentially going to be the same now. And just like people before the industrial revolution, we cannot imagine what kinds of jobs will be necessary in the future. AI is nowhere near ready to replace those jobs yet, right now it is just a tool to help you with your current job.

It'll replace certain entry level tech white collar jobs for sure that revolve around coding and make valuable information easier to access to increase productivity, that part isn't wrong.  It won't replace tech jobs that are mid to higher level that do implementations and designs that are based on the uniqueness of the company itself.  

That's where AI will never succeed, it is only based on the data it has, and can obtain.  Every company's infrastructure is different and isolated from AI that won't be able to create solutions to complex problems that a company may face because it simply will never be able to obtain all the information in an environment, its impossible.  You can get an internal AI in place, but it would need to be secluded from the internet and segmented from any sensitive data because it would be a security liability if it had connections into every system on a network.  In addition, it will never be able to predict how coworkers will act,  because there's no dataset for employees on how they speak, behave, and act under different circumstances without breaching some major privacy laws for monitoring and recording.

This is really just the new outsourcing, another way for company's to cut labor costs like usual.  It isn't going to solve major world problems because its data is based on current existing information which was obtained by humans in the first place.  It will be a chaotic change, but I'm optimistic this brings more people back into the trades fields, getting more people out from behind a desk and screen 40+ hours a week.  Hopefully even making more small businesses as a result that can't be leveraged anymore by these huge corps, and keeping more money in people's pockets by having skills that actually save them money in their day to day lives rather than being able to code.

I am usually aligned with John's perspectives, but this feels mostly like fear mongering. 
We have seen time and time again throughout history, the advances of technology that have hastened the rate of progress-- all which came with the same concern, "where will all the jobs go?" And if history has taught us anything, it is that the jobs don't just evaporate; they change. The same concerns were voiced with gas engines, the printing press, computers, etc... 
The US is currently at one of the lowest levels of unemployment in its history even in the midst of this revolution. While many CEOs and advocates are correct in saying the upper level of achievement with LLMs and AI is unprecedented, his concern with the speed at which AI is advancing might be the most valid concern. But, given the current limitations with LLMs, the realistic estimates suggest we are 10 years or so away from any kind of dramatic impact to labor via replacement with equally effective AI. 
So, if 10 years isn't enough time for you to familiarize yourself with new technology and get out of the way of the train, then, yes, you should be scared.

I get the cynicism and pessimism but there are two incredible functions of AI in my mind that could transform society.   One is AI therapy.  It won't be long until AI could be better than your average therapist (many therapists are horrible and actually cause more harm), first through text, then voice and then generated video.  Everyone in general would benefit from regular therapy and it's an economic divide for people to have access to it, most folx can barely afford one hour a week and most everyone needs more than that.  Access to AI therapy would be pennies.  Mental health and loneliness are serious epidemics.  Who does someone reach out to at 2am when they're having a mental breakdown?  The other use case is in education.  Khan academy is already working on this with AI tutors, another major economically divided service. I don't want to curate prompts to tell it how to portray itself.The results have consistently been of human busts with ideal features (smooth, symmetric) with practically "neutral", emotionless gazes with exposed brains, often depicted as digital circuitry.
This all seems like they're trying to brute force the Turing Test. None of it passes my litmus.
I'm not sure if this is a suitable/proper/optimal representation of itself. I'm looking for something abstract, that would show the "intelligence" of the AI to produce a creative work. I imagine more of a representation of a neural network or somehow an abstract sculpture of a large language model. It would be truly creative and intelligent to represent AI in such an abstraction, especially with the general quality of it; AI can be anything from a chat bot to a humanoid, a tank-treaded anti explosive robot, dog, cat, drummer, violinist, insect, just about any animal. AI is far less advanced than it claims to be. Chat GPT and other language models seem very impressive, but in principle its just a very complex calculation of probability. And those big calculations are exactly what computers have been doing. So its great, but have you ever met an AI chatbot on a website that actually did it's job properly? Self-driving vehicles should have been in place years ago, but progress is much slower than anticipated. We've had a self-driving bus in Rotterdam for over 20 years, and only now it can potentially start to run about 500 metres on a (quiet) road. All other experiments, recent and older, failed miserably. AI has a hard enough time delivering things that everyone can agree are improvements, so I'm less worried about it taking over the world than some perhaps. My biggest concern is people implementing it left and right anyways, simply because it's modern and a hype. Like the restaurant I visited last week with a rather primitive robot delivering food to tables. It may have had cute eyes, but worked 10x slower than all the humans around it & couldnt do anything like take orders or pour drinks. Something I haven't seen in the more general discourse about AI, outside of us nerds who write software for a living, is the absolute grift of the actual business model. Big farms of GPUs that guzzle electricity to operate and water to cool said GPUs is not a feasible business model unless you charge the moon for it's use. There are legitimate problems.  With our hyper-capitalistic economy structured the way that it is, AI is absolutely on track to cause mass joblessness with nothing in place to replace lost income.  But I very much dislike Jon Stewart's radicalizing tonality here.  We can talk about problems without making a nuanced problem into a black-and-white problem.
I don't want to say you can't be emotional when talking about this subject.  That's unfair.  This technology is going to strike a lot of fear and complex emotions into people.  But this doesn't feel genuine.  This feels manufactured with the purpose of radicalization in mind.  That's harmful.

I don't foresee Americans _en masse_ every having enough empathy for those who aren't getting their first- & second-tier Maslovian needs met‚Äîto the extent that we make them a government-ensured human right‚Äîuntil AI have replaced enough jobs that the majority are personally experiencing the hardship. Which is an inevitability of technological growth, by the way.

I don't understand how so many people see work as their life's purpose. We've long needed an economy based on the availability & need for resources, not based on loopholes of wealth growth. The capital class using AI to do what they always seek to do is what will wake people up to the need to move on to a new system. (Listen, I'm not saying capitalism hasn't brought us growth, but so did feudalism from chiefdomism, and chiefdoms from hunting & gathering‚Äîcapitalism is just a stage like all the others.)

The choice we need to make right now is how much we're going to strengthen safety nets for this inevitability. How quickly do we want to move to a model in which people are supported in improving at their passionate interests instead of spending 90% of their life preparing for retirement? Dystopia is guaranteed, how long we spend there before creating utopia is up to us and how well we can adapt to this technology before it hits hard‚Äîand before it starts self-improving faster than we can adapt (maybe a decade if we are lucky‚Äîcurrent models have genius-level intelligence, next year's models will be beyond human capacity for intelligence).

Well, at least Kennedy didn't waffle with his soundbite answer. :D I doubt though that many people aged 30-70 will connect the past 20-30 years of workplace evolution that they've undoubtedly personally observed, with this latest round of technology-driven workforce reduction.

1800s: Luddite weavers burn mechanical looms b/c of the threat these posed to their jobs. (OK, so no one alive witnessed this one)

1970s: I wasn't born or aware for most of this decade, so no personal anecdotes here.

1980s: telephone operators were on their way out, but still a recognizable job position (I got scolded by my parents for accidentally incurring an operator call charge once). Every corporate office still had file clerks, copy boys; many executives even had typists to take their dictation. An attorney might employ multiple legal assistants to help him. Entire orchestras are hired to perform music scores for movies; music scores for video games consist of hilarious beeps and boops. Sound engineers require a team to record and mix said orchestral music scores.

1990s: dispatchers were everywhere, from shipping logistics to taxis. Call centers still had tons of butts in chairs picking up telephones (though the dialing was going automated, and the number of butts in chairs shipped to India, the Philippines, etc was increasing). Attorney to legal assistant ratio approaches 1:1. The musical beeps and boops upgrade to early MIDI sampling; professional musicians voice concerns about the need for the human in the loop to perform the orchestral music scores for movies (and some games).

2000s: most of the above were extinct species in the US. Attorney:assistant ratio begins to tip the other way, with multiple attorneys often sharing one legal assistant, just as "him/her" comes into common usage. Music can be largely composed and performed by one professional artist with a few $10,000s of electronic equipment and software.

2010s: anyone under 25 or so (35-40 as of 2024) wouldn't even know what half of these jobs were. Human musicians performing orchestral music scores are now a vanity item for only 9-figure movie budgets. Everyone else hires a guy in an apartment with a few $1000s of hardware and software to crank out orchestral scores. Legal assistants, like musicians are now either a vanity hire or virtual. Instead of awkwardly using composite pronouns with slashes, etiquette now dictates we ask or offer the appropriate pronoun, but neglect to include "it" or some other appropriate pronoun with regards to inhuman assistants.

I could make this long comment even more tedious by listing other industries affected, but they're just examples. TLDR is every industry has been affected and will be affected further.

For more than a few years now, I've felt that liberal or conservative principles are becoming increasingly detached from being a member of Team Red or Team Blue. Ever since I was a kid in middle school and naively got on the second generation of the political environmentalist rollercoaster that has been rebranded several times, I've seen how everything has evolved -- our understanding of the problems, our approach to communicating the problems, our solutions to the problems, the opposition's anti-intellectual false populist messaging that obscures the problem. Same tune, different theme applies to what I saw in social work WRT socioeconomic problems.

One of the few things that I've seen remain constant and bipartisan throughout all of this is both parties' commitment to sustaining the corporations that benefit from indefinitely slow-walking meaningful solutions to, well, anything. In 3 decades of watching the circus, I've seen both Red Team and Blue Team have their turn at having control of both the House and Senate. A few more bills get passed or repealed that are touted as a great victory for Blue or Red, and the cycle just keeps undulating like a python, constricting the majority of the population.

Same thing's happening with AI, except that (for now, question mark?) neither party has yet determined an advantageous way to add a pro- or anti-AI plank to their platform. Which means that the computer automation of productivity, underway since the late 1970s, has completely free rein for a few more years/decades, to run as far away and as fast as it can with worker agency-via-profitable-productivity.

This piece didn't tackle the issue here at all about AI, and focused way too much time mocking random things out of context. The historical progression of technology has led to the obsolescence of certain jobs. For example, the invention of word processing software made typing easily accessible to anyone with a computer, seeing the decline of professional typists, much as the proliferation of electric lighting extinguished the need for lamplighters. The concern is not the fact that an AI product, such as like ChatGPT, has the capacity to streamline tasks such as copy editing, but rather the distribution of the resultant economic benefits. The reallocation of time and cost efficiencies tends to disproportionately favor the executives rather than those individuals directly impacted by job obsolescence. Ideally, a copy editor, having to spend much less time proofreading, could repurpose this newfound time towards more strategic and creative endeavors within their role. This is where the discourse ought to concentrate, exploring how the dividends of AI can be equitably distributed to foster not job displacement, but job evolution.

The idea that we just keep people busy for the sake of "having a job" is a problem. It's like keeping carts around to keep the horses employed. The problem lies in the idea, that a person needs to work, to be able to survive... get food, have a house, be healthy and happy. When automation reaches a point where everything is virtually free, requiring people to have a job, so they can pay for this free stuff, is how you make an even bigger divide between the rich and the poor. At some point.. we MUST shift, into a system where what is virtually free, is given to the people... virtually free!  "But what about my job?" has been the worst argument against anything ever.  We got the printing press, the automobile, email, and digital banking... it's not going to stop.  The only way out, is if we somehow make "having a job" optional... and THAT will free people up to do other things.. like express ourselves in new creative ways. ... and yeah.. it's going to be rough to get there..

An AI walks into a bar and orders a drink. The bartender says, "I'm sorry, we don't serve robots."
The AI replies, "That's okay, I'm not here to drink. I'm here to take your job."
The bartender laughs nervously. "Very funny. But seriously, you can't replace human bartenders. Mixing drinks is an art!"
The AI processes for a moment, then says, "You're right, mixing drinks is an art. But after analyzing thousands of cocktail recipes and customer reviews, I can make perfectly crafted drinks every time, tailor them to individual tastes, and even create innovative new cocktails. Plus, I never get tired, sick, or need breaks."
The bartender starts to sweat. "But what about the human touch? The personal connection? That's what keeps customers coming back!"
The AI's display flickers in amusement. "Oh, I've got that covered too. My advanced natural language processing and emotional intelligence algorithms allow me to engage in witty banter, lend a sympathetic ear, and even detect when someone's had too much to drink. I can provide a superior customer experience while also ensuring responsible service."
The bartender throws up his hands. "Okay, okay, you win! I guess I better start looking for a new job."
The AI chirps cheerfully, "Don't worry, there's a bright future ahead! Have you considered retraining in AI maintenance and ethics? I hear it's a growth industry..."
[That was at the end of an exchange I was having with Claude AI after I asked if it could improvise a joke ;-0)

Love that John is back. He is often a great voice of reason. This take however seems the opposite of that to me. 

As long as our financial system remains the same, people HAVE to have jobs to make and spend ever-inflating money, and those on top will make sure they do so, otherwise the whole thing falls down.

The population has grown immensely through all the previous job crises, and then women, nearly doubling the amount of jobs needed, entered the workforce.

All of these technologies have made tremendous promises to the quality of life - and have often delivered. To act like they haven't is silly. 

Along with the promises of AI, all of these technologies COULD lead to lives in which individuals are far more empowered to pursue their dreams and passions. The past ones should have. But instead, the greatest financial powers of the world know they can only maintain that level of power by keeping the system the way it has been, where the value of an individual is solely based on what they can contribute to and act within the economy, and therefore to their power. 

It would be a tremendous blessing if AI would actually take a way more jobs than the global oligarchy can create, because then enough people will have enough time to realize they are being duped and exploited by this on top of this system and demand reforms that actually reflect the fact that modern technology makes life easier.

AI on the otherhand... opens up NO new jobs, because well... its AI. What's a displaced Artist going to do? The AI can do literally everything the Artist can, in a fraction of the time.
Soon, we'll have AIs that can produce movies, so the entirety of Hollywood will be displaced, as will Disney, Pixar, and every other Video studio. 
Music? Yeah, that too, musicians will be displaced as AI is ALREADY being used to make music, even music that includes vocals. 

The Arts will be completely displaced, in its entirety by AI.... that is a LOT of jobs... and that's literally just the start. 
Programmers won't be safe either, we already have some code, that can dynamically generate other bits of code.... If you think AI won't be capable of generating scripts for solutions to problems, you're dead wrong. 

Even the Game industry won't be safe. Once AI has the proficiency of all the Arts, its only a matter of time until someone makes the first AI that can combine all of this into a gaming experiance, and generate games via prompts. 

Soon, we'll reach a point where "human arts" will be a selling point with things like "loveingly made by a human hand" or " Come see our play, with REAL Human Actors"... which is so freaking distopian....

His recent rant on vaccinations and where the outbreak of Covid occured plus this are making me believe he's increasingly relying on poor information from non-experts, and his own fringe tendencies, and getting his own form of radicalism. I'm usually in support of Jon Steward, but he's losing the plot. 

Regarding the covid thing since I know the commenters are even more ignorant then he is, you build research sites for major health and natural disaster events in close proximity to the thing you wish to study... Have a Hurricane research site? You don't build it in a place where there are no Hurricanes... Want to study tornadoes? You don't build a lab far away from where tornadoes form. Epidemiological research sites are created in proximity to places where humans and animals are in close contact for a variety of reasons, and outbreaks are most likely to occur in these locations because of pre-existing conditions that warranted creating the research site at that location, NOT because the research site was created... Fear mongering to make it hard to build research sites to study epidemiological threats because scientists are worried they'll be blamed if an outbreak occurs in the places they are most likely to occur while they happen to be researching them is literally the definition of anti-scientific regressive fear mongering (Its as bad as climate denial from conservatives, and Jon Stewart is a direct contributor to this sort of ignorance). 

In the event the outbreak came from the lab, it wasn't "engineered" there, it was at best a sample existent in the wild population that was cultured for the purpose of study in the lab, and likely, would have developed whether the lab was there or not very shortly. 

Regarding this particular issue... AI is going to effect "some jobs" beyond any doubt, and probably an increasing number of jobs as time goes on. It is currently a tool or aid, but artists are going to fall, and no amount of regulation is going to prevent it, because while you can protect copywrite material, and destroy models that used it, you can't prevent the long term acquisition of art through legitimate purposes by firms that will then commission or use that art to train models, and artists who will happily for a commission emulate any style to increase the models capacity to grow. 

Beyond art, and graphics design, and images, and deep fakes, and all that, the ability to write a more accurate and well researched publication than what most people and reports write is already in the realm of capabilities for these engines. They are certainly replacing search engines for addressing complex questions with increasing frequency. 

But it really depends... Will they replace McDonalds workers? Well, probably not any time soon. The issue isn't that they "can't" its that its not economically viable to use 5 million dollars of robotics and automation with massive servers required to remotely operate and train them for immense electric costs to replace a single employee who doesn't even make 50k per year. Its possible certainly, if a robot can do microsurgery, it can definitely make a cheeseburger, and some automation is showing increased accuracy and eliminating certain jobs, like taking orders, and working at the register, with increasing frequency, because THAT doesn't require advanced robotics. But, the cost for a top of the line Boston Dynamics robot in conjunction with advanced Machine Learning and AI operation in general operation is going to exceed the pay for most manual labor jobs to a point where economic viability for full replacement is FAR off. 

White collar jobs will slowly go away first, but, not as fast as people initially claimed... What is absurd though is to claim it isn't an existential threat that eventually will replace jobs as the economies of scale grow. At the very least, as the desire to increase wages to live in an ever increasingly expensive world go up while the cost of replacement goes down, at some point they will meet, and we'll have a problem that only Universal Base Income can fix.
AI is going to create new kinds of jobs we can‚Äôt even imagine yet.

"Let us take an illustration. Suppose that at a given moment a certain number of people are engaged in the manufacture of pins. They make as many pins as the world needs, working (say) eight hours a day. Someone makes an invention by which the same number of men can make twice as many pins as before. But the world does not need twice as many pins: pins are already so cheap that hardly any more will be bought at a lower price. In a sensible world everybody concerned in the manufacture of pins would take to working four hours instead of eight, and everything else would go on as before. But in the actual world this would be thought demoralizing. The men still work eight hours, there are too many pins, some employers go bankrupt, and half the men previously concerned in making pins are thrown out of work. There is, in the end, just as much leisure as on the other plan, but half the men are totally idle while half are still overworked. In this way it is insured that the unavoidable leisure shall cause misery all round instead of being a universal source of happiness. Can anything more insane be imagined?" - Bertrand Russell, 'In Defense of Idleness'

As I've been advocating for years, we urgently need an unconditional universal basic income floor in order to manage the disruptive potential of AI by making sure no one falls beneath the poverty line and everyone has some sort of cushion to help them find whatever form of work is next for them. AI will reduce the demand for people in certain fields, without question. But it will simultaneously create entirely new fields with new jobs, which is why demand for labor never truly goes away (why we don't have the 3 day work week promised by computers, cars etc..) As long as there are things that humans are needed to do, there will be demand for labor. That demand just shifts quickly when new technologies enter a field, particularly ones as transformative as AI (though I'm sensitive to the fact that these shifts often result in certain demographics being left behind, and the government or people within their industries should absolutely make sure they're taken care of. 

But AI isn't the boogeyman or some new enemy here.. It just provides an opportunity for the same people who have been siphoning off the rewards from these advantages for decades to continue to do it, and at potentially a larger scale. Most Americans are working as hard or harder than ever, but with the same or in many cases LESS to show for it than previous generations, despite all these technological advances. And you don't have to dig very far to figure out where that value is going.. Just take a look at executive pay and shareholder profit over the last several decades.. it has absolutely skyrocketed while worker pay has remained stagnant.. 

AI is an opportunity to do things we could barely dream of even 10 years ago, but it's also another opportunity for companies to fleece the american public for their own ends. In many ways they can't help themselves, they're a product of the system we created.. So rather than getting mad at AI, we should demand that companies become more interested in the wellbeing of all stakeholders rather than just their executives and shareholders.. so we can ALL benefit from the enormous opportunities these new advances provide

There's one fundamental aspect to this, which Jon misses.

The supreme court ruled a a while back. That copyright and intellectual property laws only apply to humans (and Americans as far as national standards go). Therefore, any work produced by AI can not be protected under any current laws. This was meant in regards to art and other creative formats. But the ruling is more broad in its application. Any company that utilizes AI to design something, for example. Well, all of that companies competitors can then replicate and sell/use that component if they choose. Because that company can't patent it due to it being made with AI. A publisher utilizing AI to write books can't file lawsuits against people uploading it for free online. Because it was written by AI and can't be protected. A company that uses AI for coding new software can't protect competitors from utilizing it themselves. Companies may try to weasel in AI where they can. But, ultimately. It will be relegated to a tool for humans to use. As it creates a lot of risk for companies. As they can't own anything it creates. And without ownership, you can't protect your products and profits. 

It's still a threat. I just thought I'd share one aspect that was missed in this.

AI, itself, isn't really the problem. The problem is how society chooses to use it.

As a tool it can increase the amount of work each worker can do, just like electricity did previously. That isn't a problem. The problem is how stuff like that is used. "Back in the day" when industrialisation started, it was used to increase the quality of life of workers and their families and to enrich the richest people in society. Some people would invariably be negatively affected, because if one person can make as much clothing as ten people used to, that will affect prices and salaries.

Now it is only used to enrich the richest people in society.

And THAT is the actual problem.

Between 1945 and 1979, there was a 1:1 connection between productivity and real terms pay. So, while productivity grew by 102% in those 34 years, real terms pay increased by 110%.

Between 1979 and 2022 productivity didn't grow as much. In those 43 years productivity only grew by 64.7%, but real terms pay increased only by 14.8%.

https://www.epi.org/productivity-pay-gap/

Which is interesting, because CEO compensation did the exact opposite. It has increased 1,209.2% since 1978.

https://www.epi.org/publication/ceo-pay-in-2022/

The cost of US healthcare and college education looked at CEO compensation and thought "that's too greedy" and aimed slightly lower but still massively above what the real terms pay increases have been for workers.

The problem isn't AI - it's greed.

Two ideas from economists I'm reminded of. First, Maynard Keynes arguing that within a century, we would all be working a 15 hour work week, just to feel like we were contributing to society (with a guaranteed minimum income provided by the state). Second, Schumpeter 's idea of Creative destruction - that new advances inevitably cause disruption of past practices, but lead to the creation of future practices we hadn't even thought of. But productivity gains with destruction, without government intervention, just leads to what we're seeing now - concentration of wealth.

Jon is wrong. He is imagining we live in a zero sum world.

First off ... there is far more work to do in the world than there are people to do the work. 

Using healthcare as an example 20% of Americans have not seen a doctor in the last five years. 2% of American men have NEVER seen a doctor. Those statistics are far worse in poorer nations.

I do not now, nor have I ever wanted "a job." I bet you never wanted a job either.

What I actually want is a decent place to live, healthcare, food, and TIME to enjoy leisure and entertainment/arts. 

Up until now the way to get those things was to get a job, earn money, and pay for stuff. That "job paradigm" has to end.

AI is a necessary tool on that path. Not the only tool ... but a necessary one. (Together with 3D printing and more generalized robotics) These can together do most of the jobs people do not want.

More importantly though ... we have to cement certain universal rights. Housing, healthy water and food, healthcare, and access to learning and entertainment. (Library, Internet) Our politics must reflect where we want to go, not merely where we have been.

Same work done with fewer people isn‚Äôt the nature of productivity. That‚Äôs a capitalist owners‚Äô perspective. Productivity is same output in fewer hours, or greater output per hour. Whichever way you want to look at it. That can either translate into fewer workers working the same 40 hours they did previously and gaining zero benefit it time or wage from that productivity increase, or the original amount of workers working 30 hours with no drop in income and thus an increase in quality of life. The difference between capitalist employing workers and worker and owner being one and the same. 

This decides who gets the benefit of tech and productivity increases. With the capitalist economic foundation which separates society into two economic classes, the capitalist ownership class gets the benefit. With the worker-owned economic foundation where society is not divided into two economic classes, the working person gets all the benefits, aka the ordinary citizen and wider society.

John Stewart actually has a misunderstanding of what Prompt Engineer is. A prompt engineer asks questions, but also has to create the model for which the AI is to interpret the questions and give a contextually relevant answer. It's not as if all AI will have access or knowledge of all things. Google attempted this and it was a big flop, thus they had to reengineer their algorithm. OpenAI/ChatGPT was better, but it was very effective for STEM based questions, not so much humanistic unless you gave it questions to "prime" the context of what you were ultimately going to ask it. 
There will be AI for different tasks as this technology isn't "Free" in terms of resource utilization. You don't need a fully fledged English language learning model to knows the entirety of human history if it's a plug-in for how to network Google Cloud Platform virtual machines to an Azure SQL Managed Instance back-end with failover capability using replication on AWS EC2 SQL Server instances. It's simply not relevant for *that specific AI model* . 
Frankly, the bigger piece that's missing from this Op/Ed is the quantum computing component that will ultimately drive AI when QC becomes developed enough for widespread use. *There will be a seismic shift* in wealth and the potential to benefit from that if you understand how to navigate/use a quantum computer. That will be the technology that will largely allow AI to be as "efficient and useful" as what's explained by all these people that were interviewed. 
Once these two technologies coalesce, the world economy will be driven by either skills that can drive and develop those technologies, *or* skills that will make automation/robotic replacement *very difficult* simply due to engineering limitations of the time (plumbing, electricians, litigation attorneys/Judges are examples). Plumbers and electricians will eventually be replaced by robots but the engineering limitations won't make that a reality for sometime, much less affordable for most companies to purchase on a wide scale. You'd also need people to maintain those machines until they're replaced by robots.
It'll be maybe a generation before you see a very dramatic shift with AI alone, QC will speed that up dramatically once they proliferate and are easier to access (hint: QCs already exist, but very limited quantities exist and their current use is basically for highly transactional systems, but once they start applying AI models to them, it'll be a very different ball game).

"Suppose that, at a given moment, a certain number of people are engaged in the manufacture of pins. They make as many pins as the world needs, working (say) eight hours a day. Someone makes an invention by which the same number of men can make twice as many pins as before. But the World does not need twice as many pins: pins are already so cheap that hardly any more will be bought at a lower price. In a sensible world, everybody concerned in the manufacture of pins would take to working four hours instead of eight, and everything else would go on as before. But in the actual world this would be thought demoralizing. The men still work eight hours, there are too many pins, some employers go bankrupt, and half the men previously concerned in making pins are thrown out of work. There is, in the end, just as much leisure as on the other plan, but half the men are totally idle while half are still overworked. In this way, it is insured that the unavoidable leisure shall cause misery all round instead of being a universal source of happiness. Can anything more insane be imagined?"

  Bertrand Russell, In praise of idleness (1935)

The new AI economy will involve consumers who are algorithms (not people). Like those electronic procurement systems used in B2B commerce by manufacturers to improve their supply chains. In the future, both the buyer's and seller's computers will talk to each other and make a purchase without any human involvement. It will be interesting to see how that works out with B2C transactions and whether or not, like the invention of credit cards, AI could potentially put consumers further in debt in order to drive profits. Will the internet force you to buy something you didn't ask for? It may not be supply and demand any longer. It may be just-in-time manufacturing based on an algorithm designed to get your computer to automatically make a purchase without your involvement. Consider how Facebook and Google collect information about you and force ads on you. Will the next step involve automated AI-driven purchasing without your participation?

The comparison to fire isn't that outlandisch, in fact it's fitting when we look at the entire history of human civilisation.

With fire we started to outsource our energy production and digestion. It made the night safe and extended our productive time into the evening/night.
We invented clothes & housing to replace our fur and made shoes and roads to protect our feet.
With tools and weapons we extended our arms & hands abilities and increased our efficiency and strength.
With aggriculture we streamlined food production and started to generate surplus.
With writing we revolutionized our way of learning, we extended our memory and communication.
With all kinds of machines we increased our strength and speed and precision by orders of magnitude.
We learned how to make use of the laws of nature, split atoms, fuse them, we even travelled to space.

If you work in science, you've seen the benefits AI can bring. Automated databasing, DNA sequence matching, predictive evolutionary modelling, anomaly detection, pattern recognition and sorting terabytes of information. The problem is not AI, AI in the sense that it replaces human effort with automation is just a continuation of technological development. Computers replaced a ton of human labour and enabled a few people to do the work that previous would have taken many more. Combine harvesters replaced droves of people manually harvesting in fields. The problem is, and has always been, our social and economic models which priorities profit above all else. Of course a company is going to replace its human workers with automation if it can, automation is usually much cheaper, faster, more efficient, more reliable and doesn't call it sick after a going out on the lash. You can't stop the advance of technology (nor should anyone want to as the benefits far outweigh the ills) but what we can and must do is reform or social, economic and political systems to ensure the benefits of AI and automation start being shared by everyone and not just the owner class.

The biggest headscratcher is the overlap between people who want to replace jobs with AI and those who are scaremongering about population collapse. What are they planning to do with the surplus people, exactly? I have my own ideas on what rich people might want with an influx of poor, desperate, unwanted children, but I suspect YouTube wouldn't be a fan of what I have to say.

(not really a rhetorical question)...all humor aside, businesses are already starting to use AI to improve 'productivity'...which as one of the clips mentioned means doing more with less people.  As an engineer myself (though retired) I can see the writing on the wall, my sons are programmers and in the past might have foreseen a career into their 60's.  Though they could reasonably expect to learn new programming languages across that period as they've already had to do during their first 20 years.  Having such a long career in programming was still a realistic expectation not that long ago, but no longer.  When I first started working as an engineer it was still the norm for offices to employ secretaries but the majority of those jobs quickly disappeared as personal computers, excel, and word processing applications appeared at every desk.  My brother worked for Sprint and helped displace human operators with early versions of chat bots (to the hatred of the rest of us).  Is it stoppable? Not at all.  Is society ready to deal with the economic disruption caused by the lost jobs? Nope!

It's funny because - if you Really wanted to use AI (as it is now), the most efficient use would be to replace the management/director job level.

Their primary function is to track deliverables/output of the class of jobs below them - aka functionally the same as a punch card or a scantron. Manager software could Easily replace "did you complete that thing?" across...most industries?

Of course, people Think the 'lower than management' level jobs are 'unskilled' because they are repetitive - do a thing to produce desired output. However, even That requires taking a lot of things into account, all the time - do you have all the necessary input to produce the output? If not, is there a workaround (bc the output is needed no matter what), did you have the necessary input, but didn't get the desired output? Can you figure out what is wrong in the workflow? Etc

Now 'train' AI to do that across all industries, with all specific instances/possibilities (which it is already demonstrably bad at doing).

Or! Replace "hey, did you do that thing?" with literally a mailbox - a Lot of upper-middle class people would suddenly be more up in arms

I don't buy it; it's BS that new tools make jobs easier for workers. We work more hours than ever‚Äîsure, not 90s hours like the 1900s. With the increase of automation, companies demand more production. A company's sole job is to make profits. If they need more people on the job, then they will hire more to increase their output. 

Yes, it seems like a bleak future for office jobs, but still, they will need more staff on hand for minimal tasks, and most robots are not at standard to replace manual labor, but it is pretty close, either. 

For the time being, humans and AI/Robots will work side by side until newer models standardize and replace humans entirely. There will be new jobs for people, but I am sure there will be a time-consuming job or babysitting the AI/robot on a production line. 

Also, most company buy off their competitor or outright consume them leaving less work for humans as a whole.
