Anyone who is concerned that AI will take people's jobs because jobs are people's way of getting wages and paying for living expenses should consider joining a call for equal sharing of natural wealth. Or, an equal sharing of the proceeds from fees that we should charge to industries when they extract natural resources, emit pollution or otherwise degrade environmental quality.

Our income from work should not be our sole source of income. We should respect PUBLIC property rights along with PRIVATE property rights. No one should face a threat of becoming destitute depending on their employment status.

If natural wealth is shared, workers will have more latitude to leave employment situations that they find objectionable for whatever reason. (Workers can only be oppressed because we thus far do NOT respect public or shared property rights.)

Charging fees proportional to environmental impacts, then sharing fee proceeds equally, would promote sustainability AND end poverty. The change is WAY overdue. We could have a more honest and fair political-economic system.

What we now call AI has been around since the 80s when those of us in on the basement of computers downloaded Photoshop and other programs that altered reality. The media has just given it a label, like they did changing "kidnapping", prostitution, and other people who take advantage of others as "human trafficking". I guess so it seems less horrendous than it is. Yes, I remember the 80s when the first computers came to my workplace and the instructors told us "computers would give us a "paperless workplace", making those onerous and repetitive paperwork duties so much easier for all of us, as all we needed to do was point and click on boxes and easily type over mistakes (saving paper we'd usually crumple up and put in "the round file", and save it "on a cloud" saving billions in file cabiners and staffing to file and find these papers when appropriate. Instead, we've seen AI used to eliminate repetitive low skill jobs, and created MORE PAPER, as WE as workers found it necessary to PHOTOCOPY important files and FILE them somewhere WE could easily locate them in the future, to save us from dealing with what was on those papers when someone up the food chain either purposely deleted the reports or files, and WE (employees) need to prove WE did our jobs. SO in reality computers often created more problems and scheduling issues than before. For example when I was in HIGH SCHOOL, in the early 70s, our school system went from manually created report cards (we got a "day off" from classes) as our Homeroom teachers gathered paperwork from ALL our teachers, and transcribed ther grades onto our report card,. This usually fell on a Friday and on the following Monday, our report cards were handed out, we "delivered" them to our parents, who signed them (my mother usually signed them with the now NON politically correct but legal name she acquired when she said "I do" to my father, as MRS RAY *******. Yes in the 60s and  70 s she accepted that she was no longer Helen *********, but "property" of my father, and head of our household, Mr Ray L ******. During a recent painting of the house, we stumbled upon these "historical documents" and my daughter found out "dad" was not as smart as hed been portrayed for her 36 years, but in a day when failing to turn in homework put a ZERO in a teacher's grade book, and failing a test or exam did not leave me with a  60% as my grade if I failed, but if there were 100 questions and I missed 60 of them, the grade was a 40, which dragged down all my other grades that semester even further. Recently a local scandal was exposed by the news when they found out a newly hired Superintendent decreed 60 was the worst grade a teacher could give because state aid and passing the state required "SOLs" (Standards of Learning) requirements were based on the gross number of a school's passing (C or better) students determines IF schools individually are state certifed. State law allows parents of students in "failing" schools to demand their urchins be transferred to CERTIFIED schools (of which there currently NO Middle schools that passed in my city). So we could charge our school system of "cooking their books".

The way the modern Big Tech sphere seems to view technology confuses me. Actually, I‚Äôm not just confused by it, I‚Äôm disturbed. 

You see, I love technology and inventions. Gadgets! Gizmos! Contraptions! Computer wizardry! Big machines! Little machines! Robots! These things naturally inspire glee in us. It‚Äôs the creative problem solving involved, the tactile feedback of interacting with specialised tools and parts, the sense of anticipation and accomplishment, the wonderment in seeing otherwise impossible things occur. Getting absorbed in fashioning new tools and tricks is this fantastic emergent element of the human species. It‚Äôs something we should be able to celebrate‚Ä¶

But there‚Äôs something about the Silicon Valley ethos, which has permeated our culture over the last two decades, that seems bafflingly out of touch with all of that. Apple, for example, has legitimised the practice of sealing off the inner-workings of their products from customers, practically forbidding repair and punishing anyone who tries to experiment with or extend their product in any way besides the ones they have already thought of and approved.

Social media giants like Facebook have stripped away the vibrant customisation and self expression that flourished in the earlier internet, where people would make their own custom webpages decorated colourfully with decals and wacky fonts. Now the sleek, sterile, inoffensive design languages of the companies who monopolise our online spaces are forced on the users. You‚Äôre lucky if you can choose a custom header. Information on how to make websites is now focused on ‚Äòlooking professional‚Äô, even if it‚Äôs a personal website, because we must always be thinking of the face we are putting on for potential employers or business partners.

VR emerges, and it‚Äôs really neat! But while it shows massive potential in creating worlds of escapism and recreation, for some reason we‚Äôre being told that what we really want to buy these headsets for is‚Ä¶ corporate zoom meetings? And‚Ä¶ working in Excel?

And with AI, as with the ill conceived ‚ÄòMetaverse‚Äô, concepts that sci fi has been grimly warning us of for decades are talked about with bizarre, uncritical enthusiasm by hypemen and spokespeople who apparently all watched Blade Runner thinking it was depicting a _utopia._ They seem to advocate for total capitulation to all technological developments, regardless of how they work, what the dangers are or what kind of a world they might create. 

‚ÄúThis thing we‚Äôve built might cause problems? Hmm, you might have a point there, but we‚Äôre going to sell it anyway because we‚Äôve got hungry shareholders to feed and $50 million in loans to pay back.‚Äù

In Big Tech, every new idea, every invention, is immediately understood through the lens of industry, marketing and monetisation. Nothing can exist if it cant be tied back to generating profit. The any notions of the world outside the boardroom are basically just hypotheticals. Interesting thought experiments, but immaterial when viewed next to this quarter‚Äôs earnings report. 

How can the spirit of tinkering and experimentation survive in an environment like that? Why build something actually helpful when you can use technology _cause problems,_ and then sell desperate people expensive solutions that barely work? Why foster a spirit of genuine collaboration, or work to make useful, beneficial tech more widely available when you can patent everything, squash competing vendors and make the whole world dependent on what you make, regardless of how crumby or poisonous it is. 

It‚Äôs a cult of callous, incurious snake oil salesmen blindly scuttling towards the scent of money. Grifters swapping tips on how to act more like a computer virus than a human being. All the while fancying themselves geniuses because they have the cash to pay smarter, poorer people to build widgets for them. The joy comes not from creating or learning, but from scoring and dominating. Constant exposure to their greed has, in recent years, gently soured the dreams of the little kid inside me who eagerly sketched designs for robots in their exercise book.

Anyone who thinks that everyone who shovels coal into a furnace can be taught computer programming has not spent enough time exploring the latter.  Saying this as someone who's *taught* programming classes.

Prior economic disruptions from t4echnological advances were offset either up front by union intervention or on the back end by first focusing on the tasks and processes that couldn't be optimized or automated away (like quality control and exception handling, or interacting with other people, animals, and plants, which can't be consistently forced into machine-predictable patterns) and then making the results of optimized labor into commodity goods, priced cheaply enough for anyone to afford.

But we're approaching the point where the potential jobs that folks would be displaced to are either out of the intellectual or physical reach of most of the folks being displaced, or when the machines can spur their own development faster than humans can.  Not everyone has the inclination and capacity to pick up engineering or art at a level that they can compete, and more folks without job income means less market for art, even without AI encroaching on _that_ space, or for high-tech toys.
So soon machines will be doing most of the productive work for humans, that is inevitable. But why should oligarchs get the profits from those industries? Nationalize everything.

Fear of machines that can liberate us from drudgery is a sign of a timid and divided society. The luddites are among the most misunderstood historical agents, their vandalism of the machinery was not a protest against automation, but against social arrangements that used technological innovation to deprive the majority of their dignity and life prospects in the face of automation. Consider this: ChatGPT doesn't process and fetch information like a search engine, it can be run offline on a single computer, much like a little brain in a box. We couldn't fit all that information into the 500GB required for the model even if we wanted to. However, its knowledge is limited to the time it was last trained. Now, consider the diminishing value of specialization. As automated systems advance, being an expert in a narrow field may soon be a liability. 

AI will decimate the traditional workforce, leaving only essential roles and a handful of decision-makers. In this environment, the question isn't if you'll lose your job to AI, only when. Rather than fearing job loss to AI, seize the moment to conceptualize groundbreaking initiatives that will become attainable as AI advances. Your limitations are about to be shattered; what will you do when the unimaginable becomes your toolkit? 

In essence, this AI mirrors our mind's quick-thinking 'system 1', spitting out immediate answers based on past data. But it's missing its 'system 2' - the thoughtful part of our brain that cross-checks and corrects when things go awry. As we build this network, expect AI capabilities to skyrocket. The power now lies in a broad understanding of how and why things work. That's your golden ticket in an age where a single individual can command what previously required teams. 

Wright Brothers to the moon took just 66 years.
Brick-sized phones to smartphones in half that time.
Facebook emerged in 2004, followed by YouTube in 2005.

AI is helpful tool, but like any tool, it only works when used by people who know what they are doing. You do not become a carpenter just by having great tools, or a programmer just by having access to a supercomputer. Similarly, you do not become a great scientist just by telling an AI to pump out a research paper (that 99% of the time will be either complete fiction, garbage, or a clone of already published research). An actual scientist can use AI as a tool to do things like help shift through images to identify something, like finding cancer cells in a library of microscope images, or classifying galaxies based on astronomical data. Or they can use it to generate an introduction to their essay explaining their research, with the crucial caveat that because they are the expert on the subject, they can read, fact-check, and edit the first draft that the AI generated for them. AI is a tool to help you do a job you know how to do, and not in any way a replacement for knowing how to do the job.

The same was said about Henry Ford creating the assembly line. More product, fewer workers. It can be put in a threatening light of meaning less jobs, or a positive one of more productivity. We've had these stages in development throughout history, and it always has the same impression on us when it's actualized. AI's no different. Granted, the assembly line didn't have the potential to become Skynet (I say that half-jokingly), but we're not talking about that sort of thing. AI's a new tool, it's here to stay, and we still have jobs after the assembly line. It could be made into a gun issue: is it the tool, or the person, or the availability... but as long as people in power‚Äîcorporate or otherwise‚Äîare corrupt, this kind of thing isn't AI's fault, it's an inevitability.

Quality of these systems is still woefully sub-par, it will yet take a long time before most jobs can be replaced with AI, mostly because it is so difficult to solve "corner cases" and get accuracy up from 95% to 100%. I'm an AI researcher and can confirm, Jon is 100% right here. All our disruption predictions were wrong.

Just look at sci-fi, and you'll see a reflection of the long-term expectation that AI would replace physical labor first, with art and "creative" endeavors being the ultimate human-only trait. In reality, the very first pre-ChatGPT AIs were already being trained to write coherent stories, which expanded to novels. Obviously now this includes most "intellectual" work too, which was also deemed seemingly unattainable.

Understanding that I may also be wrong, I will still say.. it's too late.

My advice to anyone reading this is that sadly the ship has sailed, but we can at least advocate for decentralization to prevent a few small actors (OpenAI/Microsoft, Google etc.) from having unrivalled power over our lives. He who controls the AI controls the future. 

If you see smaller players offering AIs that you actually own (eg. running on your own device, not their servers), then please support them. Not to be dramatic, but our future may well depend on the ability of smaller players to counteract the overbearing centralization efforts of huge corporations.

I would also say to support your local businesses who have not replaced humans with AI, but I know you and I probably won't. We said the same thing about not buying cheap imports to protect local industry. Any talk of people supporting more expensive human-created products or companies has sadly been disproved from history. I genuinely hope I am wrong about this though.

TL;DR: AI will replace your job and the best we can do is support decentralization to prevent a few corporations controlling everything.

This is no different than talking about the "false promises" of getting returns in the stock market. If a grifter tells you that he will get you 10x returns in one year, yea, that's ridiculous. If someone tells you that you can get 10x returns if you invest in index funds and don't touch it for a few decades, no one questions it. Current AI is being haphazardly applied with varying (usually low) degrees of success to replace some humans currently. You should check if anyone that is saying AI will replace a substaintial portion of the job market in the next few years is trying to sell you their AI tool. The real promise of AI, not by these grifters and headline seekers, is when AI actually becomes... intelligent. When AI transitions from being a tool for humans to use to save time/resources to something that can actually reason for itself, then and only then will it compete for large populations of the work force. That could take years (doubtful imo), decades, or perhaps won't happen in any of our lifetimes, no one knows for sure, and anyone who claims to be certain is either ill-informed or a grifter. I'm looking forward to the dystopian future where humans need not apply. I hope I'm alive to see that point in history. I also hope that others will be alive past that point in history.

post - humanism Posthumanism is a philosophical perspective that explores the implications of emerging technologies, particularly in biotechnology and artificial intelligence, on human existence and society. It questions traditional notions of human identity, consciousness, and agency, considering the blurring of boundaries between humans and machines, as well as the ethical and social consequences of these developments. Posthumanism often advocates for a more inclusive understanding of what it means to be human, embracing diversity and hybridity.

The AlphaGo team within Google‚Äôs Deep Mind division, after beating the world‚Äôs Alpha Go player, turned the technology on solving the Protein-Folding dilemma with an adapted AlphaGo AI model called AlphaFold. 

Biology PhD candidates would spend their entire 5 year program to solve the 3D structure of a single Protein. In 50 years, all the researchers and scientists in the world, working together had solved the structure of about 100,000 proteins, or about .05% of the 200 million total proteins. 

AlphaFold, in under 1 year, completed all 200 million.  The remaining 99.95% AND checked the answers of 50 years of the brightest minds in medicine‚Äôs work. These protein structures are vital to the understanding of virtually every disease, misfolded proteins are responsible for things like Alzheimer‚Äôs and Parkinson‚Äôs Disease. And knowing the 3D structure of these proteins is essential to the creation of vaccines, and even cures. 

To say AI might fundamentally change healthcare would be a gross understatement. It definitively already has, more in 1 year than all mankind combined, ever.

AI doesn't come for our jobs, because the word AI is being misused. In context, automation comes for our jobs. It may be computerized, but it is not sentient, it is not an alive thing making decisions. It is doing what it is made to do. So, when we think of tasks as being automated by AI, what does that really mean? 

AI is the new branding for "computer programs." Remember those? 

Programs had been rebranded to Applications by 2008. Now, pretty much any program can be considered an App, the concept of which is miles away from the Executables we're really describing. It's important not to distance yourself too much from our own common sense. Apps are computer software, literally programs, and many are written by literally purveyors of corporate law. 

They don't have artificial intelligence in corporate land, but they do have faith in their infinite growth. Corporate rule is a cancer in our legal system, transforming our government into a pro-corporate enforcement agency, stealing extra profit from underpaid workers and using it to (legally) bribe politicians, so that any law they pass should always be pleasant for corporations and limit the rights of humans who might seek justice against any corporation acting immorally. 

Corporate profits increase at the expense of our communities, and AI has nothing to do with it. The rebranding is a power grab, to help us all forget about them writing computer programs designed to manipulate us while padding their own pockets. Changing the framing from Apps to AI, gives the algorithm (or any other tool) that air of inevitability, as if programmers actually have little control over it. As if. 

Don't believe the hype.

ai removes the middle guy


AI is definitely shaking things up by removing the "middle guy" in many industries. Here are some ways it's happening:

E-commerce: Recommendation algorithms suggest products directly to consumers, bypassing the need for salespeople.
Finance: Robo-advisors invest your money based on your goals, replacing traditional financial advisors.
Customer Service: Chatbots answer customer questions 24/7, eliminating the need for human representatives in some cases.
There are both pros and cons to this trend. Here's a quick breakdown:

Pros:

Increased efficiency: AI can automate tasks and processes, making things faster and cheaper.
Lower costs: Removing the middleman can lead to lower prices for consumers.
Convenience: AI is always available, providing 24/7 service.
Cons:

Job displacement: As AI automates tasks, some jobs will be lost.
Lack of human touch: AI can't replicate the empathy and understanding of a human interaction.
Bias: AI algorithms can perpetuate existing biases if not carefully designed.
Overall, AI is changing the way we work and do business. While it may remove some middlemen, it's also creating new opportunities.

I remember when I was a kid, they still regularly used the phrase "labor-saving devices" to describe automation. They posed this lovely image of workers getting more free time because this technology would make us all so much more productive. The problem is that it is the capital class who invests in the automation, so they feel that they should get all of the benefits. In fact, they get 100% of the benefits and then eat into our share of what we used to have, leading to declining real wages while maintaining the 40-hour work week. This was not what they sold us all on. It was bait & switch.

Conservatives like to talk about "redistribution of income" to describe the working class just trying to stay even, let alone get ahead a tiny bit. The thing is that it is the capital class that has been redistributing income, but they have been redistributing it to themselves. This is not a long-term sustainable trend. Working class people need to be able to afford the necessities of life as a minimum, and having some money left over for some wants and not just needs is not an unreasonable request, especially given the high ratio of wants to needs consumed by capitalists. We need a system that works for all, not just for the dwindling percentage who have "made it." "Redistributing" some of that income back to those capitalism is redistributing it away from is absolutely essential. If there are gains to be made from this technology, we all should share in those gains.

I love Jon to death, but this take is pretty weak. People have been predicting that technological change would decimate jobs for literally centuries. The printing press. The loom. The cotton gin. The sewing machine. The telephone. The harvester. The automobile. In more recent times, the computer. Software tools. Robotics in manufacturing. Autonomous vehicles. There are a hundred more examples, I'm sure.

In all cases, these changes are disruptive. They can reshape or eliminate entire industries or classes of workers. This is challenging and life-changing for the people impacted. But to argue "progress is disruptive, therefore stop the progress" is neither smart nor viable. Notice that nobody who frets about AI "coming for our jobs" wants to roll back the clock and become a scribe, or a subsistence farmer, or a lamp lighter -- or a human calculator, stableman, or switchboard operator. We must move forward. We must also structure our governments and societies in a way to protect individuals from the worst impacts of these changes. (As a country, we do a poor job of this relative to our peers, unfortunately.)

This time will not be different. It is hubris to imagine that this new technology will be the first one to displace workers so dramatically that we'll all be walking around looking for something to do. New industries are born; new jobs and skills are needed. It has ever been thus, and so it will be with AI. And it's not coming "on Thursday"; AI has already been in development for decades, and it will be many more decades before much of the promise (and peril) can be realized. Don't buy the hype that these tech executives are selling.

Here are some key stakeholders that could be affected by this video, along with an evaluation of the potential impacts:

- AI developers/proponents - The video mocks and criticizes their job disruption claims and retraining arguments. This critical evaluation could undermine their public messaging and policy ambitions. 
- Displaced workers - It amplifies concerns these workers may have about real job prospects. While potentially validating worries, it does not offer solutions. 
- General public audiences - The satire gets people entertainingly thinking about AI issues, but runs the risk of polarization by appealing more to emotions than facts. It could spread skepticism rather than understanding.
- Policymakers - The critique of retraining as inadequate could inform policy debates, but the tone may turn some off or be dismissed as partisan instead of constructive. Facts are implied but not proven.
- Media outlets - News organizations focusing heavily on AI optimism are held up for ridicule, which challenging established narratives could impact their work. 
- Companies implementing AI - By raising doubts about the full economic and social impacts revealed so far, it could meet resistance from or face backlash within industries pursuing AI for profit motives.

Overall, while engaging various audiences to think more critically, the confrontational satirical format carries risk of emotion over substance and unintended consequences if misunderstood. However, as entertainment it effectively sparks broader debate, even if solutions remain undefined. A balanced approach incorporating its insights alongside additional perspectives could maximize benefits and minimize harms.

(Analysis by Generative AI Claude-Instant)

Throughout human history, new technology has always created an asymmetry of power between those who wield it and those who don't. Wielded by private, unaccountable concentrations of wealth and power (corporations) AI is poised to pour gasoline on the fire of the already spiraling wealth inequality epidemic and usher in a new age of techno-fuedalism and surveillance capitalism. Every promise that new tech would allow us to live easier and work less has been broken, and instead increases in productivity have only made the rich richer while everybody else has to work harder and longer to make ends meet.
Ah yes, the ol' "Freeing us up" and "giving us more time" argument.  For those who have had their time "freed up", how are they paying for rent/food/etc.?

The elegance of free markets lies in their self-regulating nature. As productivity increases and fewer workers are needed for a task, those who are productive can command higher incomes. However, there's no incentive to manufacture goods if consumers lack the means to purchase them. It's a delicate equilibrium between production and consumption ‚Äì one cannot exist without the other. Today's lucrative profession might become obsolete tomorrow, underscoring the importance of adaptability in the face of economic shifts. While the temptation to resist change might loom, embracing fluidity is crucial for thriving in dynamic markets.

If the $$ savings from "time-saving, productivity-enhancing" technology accrued to the worker instead of the corporation, we could be living in a more utopian world. But we all know corporations will just toss us in the trash heap along with last year's software.

I've been a freelance writer for over 11 years getting plenty of work from all kinds of companies, but in the last 12 months, so-called "AI", or simply algorithmic software (a less marketable brand name) has indeed been decimating the industry. Nobody is talking about it in the media at all. A lot of companies, especially modern app companies, are getting hopeful new writers to write full and detailed outlines with even up to half an entire script before agreeing to a contract. They then turn them down, steal their work, run it through this software to change it enough to avoid copyright laws, then they pay some teenager peanuts to correct and adjust. The product is different enough to pretend similarities were coincidence, but also badly written and soulless, removing any kind of worthwhile meaning or often even basic craft to anything.

It's absolutely appalling what this software is now being used for and nobody can really prove it, especially when more and more people are now working for companies that are based overseas and all over the place. I think we are now reaching the actual fabled tipping point where our technology will either free us (ie, from the necessity to work in order to have basic shelter, food and clothing) or it will do the opposite at the hands of rapidly dominant corporations, billionaires and the patsy politicians they help put in place to facilitate them.

Honestly, the loss of employment doesn't bother me. I can fill time. It's the loss of livelihood that worries me, because I don't think infinite money and a full AI workforce would lead to anything but poverty and starvation and maybe a rebellion or two.

AI will go as far as it can as long as there is a market for whatever it can replicate, it will stop being of use however as soon as there are no consumers left who can afford to purchase whatever it is that they produce. This is accelerating the process where the only thing of value that biological humans represent is their ability to purchase things and services, or to put it in corporate jargon "our valued customers". When biological humans cannot produce a profit to justify a salary, they will stop being an asset and become a burden. This was prophetically articulated in the 1975 film Network, in one of the lesser famous Howard Beale (Peter Finch) monologues: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NcpWk2WKhEM

Because the entire corporate/financial system is built around maximizing profits to satisfy investors, there will always be a race to maximize efficiency.  This will be the ultimate test of the viability of that premise.

AI and automation in general will drastically change our economy. Our current economic system depends on even the lowest paid workers to be consumers. It's hard to participate in the economy at all if you don't have a job. 

This means not only will the middle class shrink, but so will the rich, as consumption dwindles. Automation may allow for the rich to trade amongst each other, but those who own the automation will be those who have already accumulated large amounts of secure capital and can adapt to this change. They will produce their own goods and services for each other, and most of the rest of us won't even be useful as slaves - we'll just be in their way. And it's easy to imagine what happens then.

Or perhaps we fight now to make sure (if it's possible) that automation resources are controlled by the masses and work to everyone's benefit. 

Either way, capitalism as we know it will fall. What do we want post-capitalism to look like?

This is the conundrum with technology.  When a technology is invented that is capable of doing labor currently done by humans, faster, better, and cheaper‚Ä¶what are we supposed to do with it?  We don‚Äôt want people to lose their jobs, but at the same time, it‚Äôs terribly inefficient to support a vastly inferior industry full of human labor when technology exists that can do it better.

For example, would it have been better if we decided not to build a railroad so we wouldn‚Äôt put the farrier and horse breeding industries out of business?  Should we still be out on farm fields with hand tillers because animal drawn ploughs would put too many farmers out of work?

I mean, look I‚Äôm sorry to say it, but if AI winds up doing level 1 support better than human technicians, then they‚Äôre going to be replaced, and they should be replaced.

The issue here isn‚Äôt the technology, it‚Äôs the fact that the rich and corporations benefit from new technology far more than the working class, and the working class often suffers as technology takes their jobs and they are left out in the cold.

Me: What are the sector of the USA's economy will be unaffected by the implementation of AI in the workforce?

ChatGPT3.5: It's challenging to predict with certainty which sectors of the economy will be entirely unaffected by the implementation of AI in the workforce. However, some sectors may be less impacted due to the nature of their work or the complexity of tasks involved. Here are a few examples:

    Healthcare: While AI can augment certain aspects of healthcare such as diagnostics and administrative tasks, the human element of patient care and decision-making is likely to remain crucial.

    Creative industries: Fields like art, music, literature, and design rely heavily on human creativity and expression, which AI struggles to replicate fully.

    Personal services: Jobs that involve personalized and direct human interaction, such as personal trainers, therapists, and counselors, may be less susceptible to automation.

    Education: Teaching and mentoring require complex interpersonal skills and adaptability to individual student needs, making it challenging for AI to fully replace human educators.

    Some niche industries: Certain specialized or highly customized sectors where tasks require a high degree of creativity, adaptability, or human judgment may also be less affected by AI.

However, it's important to note that while certain sectors may be less impacted by AI in terms of job displacement, they could still experience changes in workflow, efficiency, and job roles due to the integration of AI technologies. Additionally, the pace of AI development and adoption is rapid, so even these sectors may not remain entirely untouched in the long term.

AI replacing jobs would be fine - if we accounted for it on a societal level.  We already don't all need to work for society to function - we've just collectively convinced ourselves "that's how it is".  But with AI we could have a fraction of the current workforce employed at any one time and be just fine even if we were just giving away money to everyone else.  Or we could cut back work to just one or two days a week, or have weekly rotations.  AI could free many millions of people from being pressured to work pointless jobs, give so much free time and chances at self improvement.

But we all know that won't happen.  The Industrial Revolution showed us that - you remove jobs, you push people further into poverty, you force them into worse and worse pointless jobs.  The more the people are forced to fight to survive the less time they have to ask questions about how society is run.  And those in charge do not want that - which is why they blatantly lie about how much they themselves work in order to convince people too tired or apathetic to question it to just 'be content' with the hand forced upon them.
